abstract: pmc BMC Oral Health BMC Oral Health 53 bmcorhl BMC Oral Health 1472-6831 BMC PMC12482573 PMC12482573.1 12482573 12482573 41023659 10.1186/s12903-025-06908-0 6908 1 Research Evaluation of the effect of melatonin and ascorbic acid on bone healing in a rat model of osteoradionecrosis induced by tooth extraction http://orcid.org/0000-0002-7784-9809 Keldal Göksal drgoksalkeldal@gmail.com 1 http://orcid.org/0000-0002-0807-9089 Çolak Sefa 1 http://orcid.org/0000-0001-6802-2984 Avcı Gülhan Güler 2 http://orcid.org/0000-0002-3722-2542 Gevrek Fikret 3 1 https://ror.org/01rpe9k96 grid.411550.4 0000 0001 0689 906X Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Faculty of Dentistry, Tokat Gaziosmanpaşa University, Ali Sevki Erek Yerleskesi,, 2 https://ror.org/01rpe9k96 grid.411550.4 0000 0001 0689 906X Department of Radiation Oncology, Faculty of Medicine, Tokat Gaziosmanpaşa University, 3 https://ror.org/01rpe9k96 grid.411550.4 0000 0001 0689 906X Department of Histology and Embryology, Faculty of Medicine, Tokat Gaziosmanpaşa University, 29 9 2025 2025 25 478159 1488 21 5 2025 3 9 2025 29 09 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Background Radiotherapy applied in the treatment of head and neck cancers significantly increases the risk of developing osteoradionecrosis (ORN). As there is no universally accepted standard treatment protocol for ORN, evaluating the potential therapeutic effects of antioxidant agents such as melatonin and ascorbic acid is of great importance. This study aimed to investigate the effects of these agents on bone healing in an experimental ORN model through histopathological and immunohistochemical analyses. Methods A total of 41 young-adult male Wistar-Albino rats were included in the study. All rats in the experimental groups received a single 20 Gy dose of radiotherapy, followed by tooth extraction seven days later. Group G3 received 20 mg/kg of melatonin intraperitoneally for 21 days post-RT and tooth extraction. Group G4 received 100 mg/kg of ascorbic acid intraperitoneally for 21 days. Group G5 received a combination of melatonin and ascorbic acid (20 mg/kg + 100 mg/kg) for the same duration. Immunohistochemical analyses were performed to evaluate bone healing, focusing on the expression of Bone Morphogenetic Protein-2 (BMP-2), Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP), Osteonectin (ONC), and Tartrate-Resistant Acid Phosphatase (TRAP). Results ALP expression was significantly lower in the G2 group compared to both G1 and G5 ( p p p Conclusions The findings indicate that melatonin and ascorbic acid may exert protective effects against ORN by enhancing bone healing. Trial registration : Clinical trial number: not applicable. Keywords Ascorbic acid Mandible Melatonin Osteoradionecrosis Rat Tokat Gaziosmanpasa University Scientific Research Project Unit TOGU BAP Project No: 2024-13 TOGU BAP Project No: 2024-13 TOGU BAP Project No: 2024-13 TOGU BAP Project No: 2024-13 Keldal Göksal Çolak Sefa Avcı Gülhan Güler Gevrek Fikret pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025 Introduction Radiotherapy (RT), also referred to as radiation therapy, is a physical modality employed to destroy cancer cells through ionizing radiation. This form of radiation generates ions and deposits energy within tissues, leading to direct cytotoxic effects on cancer cells or inducing genetic alterations that ultimately result in cell death [ 1 2 3 4 RT is widely used alongside surgery and chemotherapy in the treatment of head and neck cancers. However, RT is also associated with several adverse effects, including xerostomia, mucositis, radiation caries, increased susceptibility to infections, and one of the most severe complications—osteoradionecrosis (ORN) [ 5 6 7 8 The pathophysiology of ORN has been extensively studied over the years. The most widely accepted mechanism today is the fibro atrophic process induced by radiotherapy, which progresses through three phases. Initially, radiation-induced endothelial damage increases vascular permeability, leading to edema, localized microvascular ischemia, and endothelial cell death, which in turn triggers chronic nonspecific inflammation. In the second phase, abnormal fibroblast activity and extracellular matrix disorganization are observed. The final phase, termed the fibro atrophic stage, is characterized by apoptosis of myofibroblasts, a reduction in cell numbers, and the accumulation of dense collagen resulting in fibrosis. These changes collectively describe the destructive and often irreversible impact of radiation on bone tissue [ 9 10 Melatonin, primarily synthesized by the pineal gland, is known for regulating circadian rhythms. It also exhibits potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties [ 11 12 13 15 16 17 Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for numerous physiological processes [ 18 19 20 21 23 The aim of this study is to evaluate the effects of melatonin and ascorbic acid on bone healing in a rat mandibular osteoradionecrosis (ORN) model induced by radiotherapy (RT) and tooth extraction, and to investigate the potential therapeutic roles these agents may play in the symptomatic treatment or prevention of ORN progression. In this context, the hypothesis of the study is that melatonin and ascorbic acid administration may reduce ORN development by promoting bone healing and improving histopathological and immunohistochemical parameters in a rat mandibular ORN model induced by RT and tooth extraction. Materials and methods Ethical approval This research was approved by the Local Ethics Committee for Animal Experiments of Tokat Gaziosmanpasa University (Approval number: 51879863-16; Date: 07.03.2024) (Clinical trial number: not applicable). All procedures were conducted in accordance with the institutional guidelines of the Tokat Gaziosmanpasa University Experimental Medical Research Center, the university’s animal experimentation regulations Animal preparation In this study, 41 young adult male Wistar-Albino rats weighing between 300 and 400 g were used. The rats were bred at the Experimental Medical Research Unit of Gaziosmanpaşa University and housed under controlled environmental conditions (20–22 °C temperature, 40–60% humidity) during the experimental period. A 12-hour light/dark cycle was maintained to simulate artificial day and night. The animals were fed with standard pellet chow (20 g/day) and had access to water (40 ml/day) ad libitum. Five rats were assigned to the control group, and the remaining 36 were allocated to the experimental groups. All experimental groups received head and neck irradiation. The same anesthesia protocol, surgical procedures, and follow-up durations were applied to all animals. The experimental protocol is schematized in Fig. 1 24 Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the experimental procedure Experimental Groups:  G1 (Control, n=5): No treatment was applied. G2 (RT+EX, n=9): A single dose of 20 Gy radiotherapy was applied, followed by extraction of the three mandibular molars on day 7; no additional treatment was given. G3 (RT+EX+MEL, n=9): In addition to the procedures in G2, melatonin was administered daily at a dose of 20 mg/kg for 21 days following tooth extraction. G4 (RT+EX+Cvit, n=9): In addition to the procedures in G2, ascorbic acid was administered daily at a dose of 100 mg/kg for 21 days following tooth extraction. G5 (RT+EX+MEL+Cvit, n=9): In addition to the procedures in G2, a combination of melatonin (20 mg/kg) and ascorbic acid (100 mg/kg) was administered daily for 21 days following tooth extraction. Irradiation and surgical procedure Radiotherapy was administered using a Varian Clinac DHX 5776 Linear Accelerator (Varian Medical Systems, Palo Alto, CA, USA) at the Radiation Oncology Department of Tokat Gaziosmanpasa University under the supervision of a radiation oncologist. General anesthesia was achieved with intraperitoneal injections of 100 mg/kg Ketamine HCl (Ketalar ® 24 Administration of melatonin and ascorbic acid Melatonin (Sigma Aldrich, St. Louis, Missouri, USA) was prepared by dissolving 2 g of powder in 1.5 ml of absolute alcohol and 90 ml of physiological saline to yield a 98.3% solution. Rats in Groups 3 and 5 received daily intraperitoneal injections of melatonin at a dose of 20 mg/kg for 21 days [ 25 26 27 Melatonin and ascorbic acid administrations were performed intraperitoneally at approximately 2 h after the onset of the light phase (around 10:00 a.m.), based on the 12-hour light/dark cycle of the rats. The timing of administration was kept consistent across all experimental groups. Sacrifice and tissue sampling On day 28 post-RT, all animals were euthanized via high-dose intraperitoneal injections of 100 mg/kg Ketamine HCl and 10 mg/kg Xylazine. Following euthanasia by decapitation, the left mandibles were surgically removed using a piezoelectric device. Surrounding soft tissues were cleared, and the regions designated for histological analysis were isolated and fixed in 4% buffered formalin for 48 h, followed by decalcification in an EDTA solution for one month. Samples were embedded in paraffin blocks in a standardized vertical orientation. Serial 4 μm-thick sections were cut using a rotary microtome (Leica RM2135, Germany) and mounted on slides for hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) and immunohistochemical staining. Hematoxylin-eosin staining Sections were deparaffinized, rehydrated through graded alcohols, and stained with hematoxylin, followed by washing, acid-alcohol differentiation, and eosin counterstaining. Sections were then dehydrated through graded alcohols, cleared in xylene, and coverslipped. Microscopic evaluation was performed using a Nikon Eclipse 200 light microscope. Qualitative assessment of the structural condition of the mandibular bone surrounding the extraction and irradiation sites was carried out in all groups. Immunohistochemical staining Four-micrometer-thick paraffin sections were used for indirect immunohistochemical staining to detect the expression of ALP, BMP-2, ONC, and TRAP. Following deparaffinization and rehydration, antigen retrieval was performed in 10 mM citric acid using a microwave. Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked with 3% hydrogen peroxide for 10 min. After rinsing in PBS and hydrophobic demarcation, non-immune blocking serum was applied for 15 min. Primary antibodies (ALP, BMP-2, ONC, TRAP) were applied overnight at 4 °C. After PBS washes, biotinylated secondary antibodies and streptavidin-HRP conjugates were sequentially applied. Immunoreactivity was visualized using aminoethyl carbazole (AEC) chromogen, followed by hematoxylin counterstaining. Negative controls were prepared by omitting the primary antibodies. Immunohistochemical analysis Immunoreactivity for ALP, BMP-2, ONC, and TRAP in the bone tissue adjacent to the irradiated and extraction sites was scored using a four-tier system (0 = no staining, 1+ = weak, 2+ = moderate, 3+ = strong) under 40x magnification with a Nikon Eclipse 200 microscope and the NIS-Elements software (Hasp ID: 6648AA61; Nikon, Japan). H-scores were calculated using the formula [∑Pi(i+1)], where is the staining intensity score and Pi is the percentage of stained cells. The mean and standard error values are collectively presented in Table 1 p Table 1 Group mean h-scores representing immunohistochemical staining intensities of ALP, BMP-2, ONC, and TRAP molecules in a single table format Group ALP (Mean ± SEM) BMP-2 (Mean ± SEM) ONC (Mean ± SEM) TRAP (Mean ± SEM) G1 216.85 ± 3.39ᵃ 243.62 ± 3.99ᵃ 173.05 ± 9.21ᵃ 96.02 ± 4.04ᵃ G2 128.09 ± 11.90ᶜ 180.07 ± 13.57ᶜ 93.78 ± 3.19ᶜ 147.74 ± 17.82ᶜ G3 159.02 ± 9.98ᵇ 198.74 ± 11.71ᵇ 102.98 ± 7.49ᵇ 130.39 ± 4.88ᵇ G4 165.07 ± 13.73ᵇ 182.66 ± 11.01ᶜ 99.25 ± 2.54ᵇ 105.69 ± 11.80ᵃ G5 222.67 ± 9.57ᵃ 224.19 ± 17.76ᵃᵇ 154.93 ± 10.80ᵃ 137.02 ± 17.43ᵇᶜ SEM Statistical analysis was performed using one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's HSD post hoc test (p < 0.05). Different superscript letters within the same row indicate statistically significant differences between groups Statistical analysis All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 22.0 software (IBM, USA). Levene’s test was applied to assess variance homogeneity. As the data met the assumptions for parametric testing, one-way ANOVA was used to compare groups. Tukey’s HSD post hoc test was applied for multiple comparisons of H-scores for ALP, BMP-2, ONC, and TRAP. Results were expressed as mean ± standard error of the mean (SEM). Statistical significance was set at p Results Histopathological Findings In the hematoxylin-eosin-stained sections of the control group (G1), normal histological architecture of the mandibular bone was observed, including intact teeth, surrounding periodontal ligaments, and alveolar bone tissue. In the RT and tooth extraction group (G2), microscopic evaluation revealed substantial tissue damage, including intense inflammation, tissue erosion, ulceration, and disrupted normal bone architecture in the socket area and adjacent tissues. In the melatonin-treated group (G3), a slight reduction in inflammation, tissue erosion, and overall damage was observed in the socket region and surrounding bone compared to G2. The ascorbic acid group (G4) showed similar histological features to G3, with mild improvements in tissue architecture and a reduction in inflammatory changes around the extraction site. In the combined melatonin and ascorbic acid group (G5), substantial reduction in tissue damage was observed. The socket area and surrounding tissues exhibited reparative tissue formation with re-epithelialization, indicating marked histological improvement. The histopathological images are collectively presented in Figure 2 Fig. 2 Representative Hematoxylin and Eosin-Stained Microscopic Images of the Study Groups (Scale bars: 250 µm) Immunohistochemical findings The highest H-score for ALP expression was observed in Group 5, followed by Groups 1, 4, 3, and 2. Statistically significant differences were noted between Group 2 and both Group 1 ( p p 3 Fig. 3 Representative immunohistochemically stained microscopic images for the ALP molecule from each experimental group (IHC-AEC, Scale Bars: 25 µm) p 4 Fig. 4 Representative immunohistochemically stained microscopic images for the BMP-2 molecule from each experimental group (IHC-AEC, Scale Bars: 25 µm) p 5 Fig. 5 Representative immunohistochemically stained microscopic images for the ONC molecule from each experimental group (IHC-AEC, Scale Bars: 25 µm) 6 Fig. 6 Representative immunohistochemically stained microscopic images for the TRAP molecule from each experimental group (IHC-AEC, Scale Bars: 25 µm) Discussion In this study, various histological and immunohistochemical analyses were conducted to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of melatonin and ascorbic acid against the adverse effects of radiotherapy on bone tissue. Accordingly, the severity of osteoradionecrosis and the levels of inflammation were assessed histologically, while the expression levels of osteonectin (ONC), tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) were evaluated immunohistochemically. The study findings revealed a decrease in osteoblastic markers (BMP-2, ALP, ONC) and an increase in TRAP levels in the radiotherapy-only group (G2), indicating enhanced osteoclastic activity and suppressed bone formation associated with RT. These results are consistent with previous descriptions in the literature characterizing ORN by increased bone resorption within a hypovascular, hypocellular, and hypoxic environment [ 6 28 The primary approach in the treatment of osteoradionecrosis (ORN) involves the removal of necrotic tissue and the promotion of tissue healing. In addition to surgical debridement, several adjunctive therapies are commonly used, including pentoxifylline, which enhances vasodilation and suppresses inflammation; a combination of tocopherol and vitamin K due to their antioxidant properties; and hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy, which supports angiogenesis and collagen synthesis [ 29 34 6 In the melatonin-treated G3 group, increased expression levels of BMP-2, ONC, and ALP were observed, while TRAP expression was decreased compared to the RT group. This trend supports the notion that melatonin enhances osteoblastic activity while suppressing osteoclastic processes. Previous studies have reported that melatonin increases bone mineral density, reduces oxidative stress, promotes vascularization and osteoblast differentiation, and directly supports osteogenesis by accelerating the expression of bone-related markers [ 13 25 35 41 42 In the G4 group treated with vitamin C, similar to the melatonin group, an increase in osteoblastic markers and a decrease in TRAP levels were observed. This trend supports the osteoblast-promoting and osteoclast-inhibiting effects of vitamin C. Previous studies have also associated the osteoprotective effects of vitamin C on bone tissue with enhanced osteoblastic activity and suppressed osteoclastic processes [ 43 45 46 49 The study findings revealed a decrease in osteoblastic markers (BMP-2, ALP, ONC) and an increase in TRAP levels in the radiotherapy-only group (G2), indicating enhanced osteoclastic activity and suppressed bone formation associated with RT. These results are consistent with previous descriptions in the literature characterizing ORN by increased bone resorption within a hypovascular, hypocellular, and hypoxic environment [ 6 28 The primary approach in the treatment of osteoradionecrosis (ORN) involves the removal of necrotic tissue and the promotion of tissue healing. In addition to surgical debridement, several adjunctive therapies are commonly used, including pentoxifylline, which enhances vasodilation and suppresses inflammation; a combination of tocopherol and vitamin K due to their antioxidant properties; and hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy, which supports angiogenesis and collagen synthesis [ 29 34 6 In the melatonin-treated G3 group, increased expression levels of BMP-2, ONC, and ALP were observed, while TRAP expression was decreased compared to the RT group. This trend supports the notion that melatonin enhances osteoblastic activity while suppressing osteoclastic processes. Previous studies have reported that melatonin increases bone mineral density, reduces oxidative stress, promotes vascularization and osteoblast differentiation, and directly supports osteogenesis by accelerating the expression of bone-related markers [ 13 25 35 41 42 In the G4 group treated with vitamin C, similar to the melatonin group, an increase in osteoblastic markers and a decrease in TRAP levels were observed. This trend supports the osteoblast-promoting and osteoclast-inhibiting effects of vitamin C. Previous studies have also associated the osteoprotective effects of vitamin C on bone tissue with enhanced osteoblastic activity and suppressed osteoclastic processes [ 43 45 46 49 In the G5 group, where melatonin and ascorbic acid were administered in combination, BMP-2, ALP, and ONC expression levels increased, and TRAP expression decreased—similar to the G3 and G4 groups. These findings indicate that the combined use of melatonin and vitamin C promotes osteoblastic activity while suppressing osteoclastic processes, thereby positively influencing bone regeneration. This dual effect is particularly noteworthy in clinically challenging conditions such as osteoradionecrosis (ORN) following radiotherapy, due to its potential to accelerate bone healing. Indeed, a study on human lymphocytes demonstrated that the combination of melatonin and ascorbic acid significantly reduced X-ray–induced genotoxicity when administered prior to irradiation, as evaluated by the micronucleus assay [ 50 51 This study was conducted using an experimental animal model to evaluate the effects of melatonin and ascorbic acid on radiation-induced bone damage. However, there are certain limitations regarding the translational applicability of the findings to clinical settings. First, the rat model used in this study differs physiologically, anatomically, and metabolically from humans. Bone healing in rats occurs more rapidly, and their systemic responses to pharmacological agents may not fully reflect those in humans. This discrepancy limits the direct clinical translatability of the results. Additionally, melatonin and ascorbic acid were administered via the intraperitoneal route. Compared to commonly used human routes (oral or topical), intraperitoneal administration results in higher bioavailability. Therefore, the effects of these agents may vary depending on the dose, duration of administration, and pharmacokinetic characteristics. Another important limitation of the study is the lack of radiographic imaging to evaluate potential root fractures, residual tooth fragments, or osteolytic changes following tooth extraction. The absence of radiographic assessment may have led to the omission of early signs of bone resorption and introduces potential bias in the interpretation of histological findings. To mitigate this limitation, histological sampling was carefully performed from macroscopically verified regions free of root remnants. Future studies incorporating pre- and post-extraction radiographic monitoring would contribute to more comprehensive and objective morphological and quantitative evaluations. Conclusion The findings of this study suggest that melatonin and ascorbic acid exert radioprotective effects against radiation-induced bone damage via two key pathogenetic mechanisms. Immunohistochemical analyses revealed a significant increase in the levels of ALP, BMP-2, and osteonectin (ONC) markers of osteoblastic activity-particularly in the group treated with a combination of melatonin and vitamin C. This upregulation indicates an enhancement of osteogenic activity supporting new bone formation. Conversely, the expression of TRAP, a marker of bone resorption and osteoclastic activity, was suppressed in the same groups. These results demonstrate that melatonin and ascorbic acid not only stimulate osteoblastic processes but also inhibit osteoclastic degradation, thereby exhibiting a dual regulatory effect. The synergistic impact observed in the combination group highlights the potential of melatonin and vitamin C as therapeutic agents in preventing osteoradionecrosis and promoting bone regeneration; however, further clinical studies are necessary to validate these findings.
